page.title: 03Undercliff-Natural History
page.content: Niton Undercliff is well supplied with fauna,including hares,rabbits, foxes,badgers and dormice.Frogs and toads have much diminished,but there are grass snakes,adders and some lizards.One or two red squirrels have been seen recently.The bird population has altered considerably in the last 40 years.All peregrine falcons were lost by pesticide poisoning but kestrels are returning.Pheasants have appeared in some quantity,and there are numerous wood-pigeons and collar- doves.Many migrant birds are attracted to the light at St.Catherine's Point, which is a favourite venue for bird watchers.Botanically the Undercliff is full of interest.Wild flowers and ferns abound,including the rare Sea Spleenwort Fern and the Purple Cow- wheat. .
